facts.text: Appeal No. 209 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 31, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 913 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal No. 209 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 31, 1964 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 913 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant, Mrs. Menezes, is the owner of a house in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Mrs. Menezes, is the owner of a house in Bombay, and the wife of the first respondent Yusuf Khan is a tenant of a part of the first floor in that house.

facts.text: The wife of the first respondent Yusuf Khan is a tenant of a part of the first floor in the appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Mrs. Menezes, is the owner of a house in Bombay, and the wife of the first respondent Yusuf Khan is a tenant of a part of the first floor in that house.

facts.text: On January 17, 1963, Robert, a servant of the appellant, called the wife of the first respondent a thief and Halkat.

anchor.surface_text: On January 17, 1963 one Robert-a servant of the appellant, called the wife of the first respondent a thief and Halkat.

facts.text: On the next day after January 17, 1963, the first respondent slapped the face of Robert.

anchor.surface_text: On the next day the first respondent slapped the face of Robert. This was followed by a heated exchange of abusive words between the first respondent and the appellants husband.

facts.text: There was a heated exchange of abusive words between the first respondent and the appellant's husband.

anchor.surface_text: On the next day the first respondent slapped the face of Robert. This was followed by a heated exchange of abusive words between the first respondent and the appellants husband.

facts.text: The first respondent threw at the appellant's husband a file of papers.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent was annoyed and threw at the appellants husband a file of papers. The file did number hit the appellants husband, but it hit the elbow of the appellant causing a scratch.

facts.text: The file of papers thrown by the first respondent did not hit the appellant's husband but hit the elbow of the appellant causing a scratch.

anchor.surface_text: The file did number hit the appellants husband, but it hit the elbow of the appellant causing a scratch. The appellant lodged information at the Bandra police station companyplaining that the first respondent had companymitted house trespass in order to the companymitting of an offence punishable with imprisonment, had thrown a shoe at her, had slapped the face of her servant Robert, and had also caused her a bleeding incised wound on the forearm.

facts.text: The appellant lodged information at the Bandra police station complaining that the first respondent had committed house trespass, thrown a shoe at her, slapped Robert, and caused her a bleeding incised wound on the forearm.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant lodged information at the Bandra police station companyplaining that the first respondent had companymitted house trespass in order to the companymitting of an offence punishable with imprisonment, had thrown a shoe at her, had slapped the face of her servant Robert, and had also caused her a bleeding incised wound on the forearm.

facts.text: The Sub-Inspector found that the appellant had suffered a mere scratch on her elbow.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector found that the appellant had suffered a mere scratch on her elbow. The appellant and Robert declined to go to a public hospital for examination or treatment, and were, it is claimed, examined by a private medical practitioner,

facts.text: The appellant and Robert declined to go to a public hospital for examination or treatment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Robert declined to go to a public hospital for examination or treatment, and were, it is claimed, examined by a private medical practitioner, who certified that the appellant bad suffered a bleeding incised wound, skin deep, size 1 in length on the right forearm,

facts.text: A private medical practitioner certified that the appellant suffered a bleeding incised wound, skin deep, size 1 in length on the right forearm, and Robert had a swelling about 1 1/2 in diameter, roundish, soft and tender, but numberbruises.

anchor.surface_text: and were, it is claimed, examined by a private medical practitioner, who certified that the appellant bad suffered a bleeding incised wound, skin deep, size 1 in length on the right forearm, and that Robert had a swelling about 1 1/2 in diameter, roundish, soft and tender, but numberbruises.

facts.text: The case was transferred from the Court of the Presidency Magistrate, Bandra, to the Court of the Presidency Magistrate VI Court, Mazagaon, Bombay, and entrusted to a special prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: The case was transferred from the Court of the Presidency Magistrate, Bandra, to the Court of the Presidency Magistrate VI Court, Mazagaon, Bombay, and was entrusted to a special prosecutor on behalf of the State.

facts.text: The Trial Magistrate held that the story of trespass was false and disbelieved the story that the first respondent hurled a shoe at the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Magistrate held that the story that the first respondent had trespassed into the house of the appellant was false and the charge of trespass was made only with a view to persuade the police officer to investigate it as a companynizable offence. The story of the appellant that the first respondent had hurled a shoe at her was also disbelieved.

facts.text: The Trial Magistrate convicted the first respondent under S. 323 IPC for simple injuries to Robert and the appellant and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 10 on each of the two counts.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Magistrate held that simple injuries were caused to Robert and to the appellant and for causing those injuries he companyvicted the first respondent of the offence under S. 323 P. Code and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 10 on each of the two companynts.

facts.text: A revisional application was preferred to the Bombay High Court against the order of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of companyviction, a revisional application was preferred to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

facts.text: The High Court set aside the conviction and acquitted the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly set aside the companyviction and acquitted the first respondent.

facts.text: The High Court found that the appellant had grossly exaggerated her story and the medical evidence did not inspire confidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the appellant had grossly exaggerated her story, that the evidence of the medical practitioner who claimed to have examined the appellant and Robert and to have certified the injuries did number inspire companyfidence,

facts.text: The High Court found that the husband of the appellant had addressed provocative and insulting abuses.

anchor.surface_text: that the husband of the appellant had addressed provocative and insulting abuses, and that in a state of excitement the respondent hurled a file of papers at the appellants husband which missed him and caused a scratch on the appellants forearm.

facts.text: The complainant's husband had beaten the first respondent's child for some rude behaviour.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainants husband had, it appears, beaten the first respondents child for some rude behaviour and Robert the appellants servant was undoubtedly rude to the respondents wife and instead of showing companytrition he said that he would repeat his rude words.

facts.text: Robert was rude to the respondent's wife and said he would repeat his rude words.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainants husband had, it appears, beaten the first respondents child for some rude behaviour and Robert the appellants servant was undoubtedly rude to the respondents wife and instead of showing companytrition he said that he would repeat his rude words.

facts.text: The Supreme Court maintains the order of acquittal passed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore maintain the order of acquittal passed by the High Court.

facts.text: This court directed Rs. 1,500 be deposited by the appellant by way of costs of the respondents when special leave was granted.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had power to invoke s. 95 I.P. Code when bodily hurt was intentionally caused to the complainant

anchor.surface_text: Before us it was urged that the High Court had numberpower to act under s. 95 I.P. Code, since by the act of the respondent bodily hurt was intentionally caused. It was argued that s. 95 applies only in those cases where the act which causes harm is actually caused to the companylainant s. 95 cannot be invoked. In s. 95 I.P. Code includes financial loss, loss of reputation, mental worry or even apprehension of injury, but when physical, injury is actually caused to the companylainant s. 95 cannot be invoked.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is no substance in these contentions. Section 95 provides Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes, or that it is intended to cause, or that it is known to be likely to cause, any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm.

arguments.claim: Expression 'harm' in s.95 IPC includes physical injury, as per dictionary meaning and usage in other IPC sections

anchor.surface_text: The expression harm has not been defined in the Indian Penal Code in its dictionary meaning it connotes hurt, injury damage impairment, moral wrong or evil. There is no warrant for the contention raised that the expression harm in s. 95 does not include physical injury.

arguments.claim: Having regard to circumstances, harm to appellant and Robert was so slight no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain; s.95 applies

holdings.text: In our view there is no substance in these contentions. Section 95 provides Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes, or that it is intended to cause, or that it is known to be likely to cause, any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm.

anchor.surface_text: In our view there is no substance in these contentions. Section 95 provides Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes, or that it is intended to cause, or that it is known to be likely to cause, any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain terms of s.95 explicitly include acts intended or known to cause harm if slight; object to exclude trivial cases from penal law.

holdings.text: The expression harm has not been defined in the Indian Penal Code in its dictionary meaning it connotes hurt, injury damage impairment, moral wrong or evil. There is no warrant for the contention raised that the expression harm in s. 95 does not include physical injury.

anchor.surface_text: The expression harm has not been defined in the Indian Penal Code in its dictionary meaning it connotes hurt, injury damage impairment, moral wrong or evil. There is no warrant for the contention raised that the expression harm in s. 95 does not include physical injury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning and consistent usage in other IPC sections like 81,87,88 etc. include physical injury; no basis for restriction.

holdings.text: Section 95 is intended to prevent penalisation of negligible wrongs or of offences of trivial character. Whether an act which amounts to an offence is trivial would undoubtedly depend upon the nature of the injury, the position of the parties, the knowledge or intention with which the offending act is done, and other related circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether, having regard to the circumstances, the harm caused to the appellant and to her servant Robert was so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm. Section 95 is intended to prevent penalisation of negligible wrongs or of offences of trivial character. Whether an act which amounts to an offence is trivial would undoubtedly depend upon the nature of the injury, the position of the parties, the knowledge or intention with which the offending act is done, and other related circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Triviality assessed contextually considering injury nature, parties' positions, provocation, relations; here slap and scratch trivial amid mutual abuses and prior rudeness.

holdings.text: But the High Court was of the view that the harm caused both to the appellant and to Robert was trivial, and that the evidence justified the conclusion that the injury was so slight that a person of ordinary sense and temper placed in the circumstances in which the appellant and Robert were placed may not reasonably have complained for that harm.

anchor.surface_text: The complainants husband had, it appears, beaten the first respondents child for some rude behaviour and Robert the appellants servant was undoubtedly rude to the respondents wife and instead of showing contrition he said that he would repeat his rude words. At the time of the incident in question, the appellants husband and the first respondent exchanged vulgar abuses. Apparently the respondent was annoyed and threw a file of papers which caused a mere scratch to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting High Court's assessment of evidence and circumstances including prior provocations, rudeness, mutual abuses justifying triviality under s.95.

holdings.text: Even granting that a different view may be taken of the evidence, we do not think that we would justified in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution in disagreeing with the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution in disagreeing with the order of the High Court. We therefore maintain the order of acquittal passed by the High Court. This court had at the time when special leave was granted directed that Rs. 1,500 be deposited by the appellant by way of costs of the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary jurisdiction under Art.136 not to interfere with acquittal where High Court's view on evidence and s.95 application reasonable.

holdings.text: We therefore maintain the order of acquittal passed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore maintain the order of acquittal passed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding High Court's application of s.95 IPC to trivial harms in the circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore maintain the order of acquittal passed by the High Court.
